text:
I know this is a bit of a nitpick, but I am trying to use the `plots`  library. The simple program
`using Plots`
`plot([sin cos])`
takes 11 seconds to run, and I am not on a slow machine. Is this normal? Is there anything that can be done to tweak julia to improve library import time?

elements.text: I know this is a bit of a nitpick, but I am trying to use the
plots
library. The simple program
using Plots
plot([sin cos])
takes 11 seconds to run, and I am not on a slow machine. Is this normal? Is there anything that can be done to tweak julia to improve library import time?

text: Yeah, this is knows as the "time to first plot" problem. Julia is JIT compiled, and the compilation takes a little time. Plotting packages are notoriously slow to compile

elements.text: Yeah, this is knows as the "time to first plot" problem. Julia is JIT compiled, and the compilation takes a little time. Plotting packages are notoriously slow to compile

text: Hi, are you new to Julia? This is the famous time-to-first-plot issue, due to Julia's compilation process

elements.text: Hi, are you new to Julia? This is the famous time-to-first-plot issue, due to Julia's compilation process

text:
Basically it's unavoidable - it's part of how Julia fundamentally works. You can mitigate it with a few methods, though:
• Keep your Julia sessions open longer using Revise
• Upgrade to Julia 1.6, which is somewhat faster than older versions
You can also do more fancy stuff, like
• Make a custom sysimg with PackageCompiler.jl with Plots.jl precompiled into the system image
• Using daemonmode.jl

elements.text: Basically it's unavoidable - it's part of how Julia fundamentally works. You can mitigate it with a few methods, though:
Keep your Julia sessions open longer using Revise
Upgrade to Julia 1.6, which is somewhat faster than older versions
You can also do more fancy stuff, like
Make a custom sysimg with PackageCompiler.jl with Plots.jl precompiled into the system image
Using daemonmode.jl

text: Ah that makes sense. So it has to compile the library and the plot function. I see that subsequent plots are a lot faster to render.

elements.text: Ah that makes sense. So it has to compile the library and the plot function. I see that subsequent plots are a lot faster to render.

text:
<https://julialang.github.io/PackageCompiler.jl/dev/examples/plots/>
Here's an example of how to make a custom system image!

elements.text: Here's an example of how to make a custom system image!

text: yes, it is certainly a bit annoying, but the focus of the language has historically been on making really slow programs fast, even if the very quick programs (just one-off plots, e.g.) get slower as a tradeoff

elements.text: yes, it is certainly a bit annoying, but the focus of the language has historically been on making really slow programs fast, even if the very quick programs (just one-off plots, e.g.) get slower as a tradeoff

text: Some other plotting libraries might be faster than Plots, GR.jl or <https://github.com/Evizero/UnicodePlots.jl> for example
